misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Methods mutate a String in place (immutability misunderstanding)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling a String method like toUpperCase() or replace(...) changes the original String object directly (i.e., the same String gets modified in memory), so you can "transform" a String without needing to store the returned value.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, String objects are immutable: methods like toUpperCase() and replace(...) do not change the existing String. They compute and return a new String. If you don’t assign the return value (or otherwise use it), the transformation is effectively lost. In this student’s code, they do assign the result to new variables, which suggests they may understand immutability—but if they’re doing it “just to be safe” or by pattern-copying, this is exactly the misconception to check for.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Often manifests as wrong output (original string prints unchanged) when a student writes userInputLine.toUpperCase(); userInputLine.replace(...); without assignment. In this submission, no error occurs because they correctly assign, but the code structure is the key place to probe their mental model.
